name: Collared Lizard
description: Belongs to a group of smaller iguana species without a dorsal crest. Males are brightly colored with dominant blue-green tones, while females are mostly brownish. Both sexes have a base body color interspersed with small dots, with pregnant females displaying striking red spots on their bellies. A double dark collar on the neck is typical for both sexes.
image_alt: Collared lizard, photo: Tereza Mrhálková, Prague Zoo
proportions: Body length 10–20 cm; tail length 10–15 cm; weight 40 g
attractions: Extremely heat-loving, it can move across rocks heated to 60°C. It remains active even during the hottest hours, hunting prey of various sizes, including other reptiles nearly as large as itself. To cool off on scorching rocky ground, it lifts its legs alternately, standing on just two at a time. When threatened, it can rear up and flee on its hind legs, similar to basilisks or anoles. Males often perch on elevated rocks for a perfect view of their territory. During courtship or to defend their territory from rival males, they perform conspicuous movements—push-ups, arching their backs sharply, and inflating their throats.
breeding: Collared lizards arrived at the zoo in 2003, initially housed in an exhibit in the Africa Up Close pavilion. They were later moved to a terrarium in the Big Cats Pavilion. By the end of 2013, over 150 offspring had hatched at the zoo.
